channel.title: Help with this faking trojan/spyware/total FAK-UP
channel.description:
Alright, well I go on my computer and notice all this crap pooping up when I'm not even on the internet, then a little thing pops oppen on the bottom of my screen saying 'Click here to block adware'. Obviously this is the trap into spyware. Well, I downloaded a spyware scanner/deleter called NoAdware V5.0 and it found a bunch of items. But the main one was this:
[code]Item:Trojan.Download.Berbew Location:HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE/SOFTWARE/Regkey(and Regvalue)[/code]
It finds it, I delete it, and to make sure, I run another scan. To find that it reinstalled itself. Well, even when I found it's location and deleted it, it seems like it hid itself in .exe's and reinstalls itself.
So someone help on deleting this :o

item.title: Help with this faking trojan/spyware/total FAK-UP
item.dc:creator: @RXVL RXVL
item.description:
@RXVL wrote:

Look, the reason you have a virus is because you have a piece of shit virus scanner. There is no other way I can say it, here, look at these stories:

I actually dumped the 2005 version of Norton Internet Security, having to reformat my drive and re-install windows 2000 to get rid of it. I had just purchased it and and didn't ask for a refund. I used AVG Free version for a year and have replaced that with NOD32 from Eset. Norton 2005 completely screwd up my system to where I couldn't use it. I recomend either AVG or NOD32, the latter being bit lighter on system resource usage.
My personal, very personal opinion is to dislike Norton for four reasons. (1) Their documentation is very difficult to read and non-informative. (2) Their support is very poor and, if acquired in person, extremely expensive. (3) Their software does a poor job of malware detection and removal and must be suplemented via use of other software agents. (4) Their software digs itself deeply into a system to the extent it is EXTREMELY difficult to remove, requiring not only uninstall but also use of utilities acquired from Symantec plus utilities acquired via Google search plus substantial effort on the computer owner's part.

Another personal gripe is the manner in which Norton/Symantec software has “wedded” itself into other products so that trial versions come pre-installed on, for example, Windows systems and Linksys routers…

My computer was working perfectly until I installed the Norton (Symantec) 2007 update for Norton Systemworks and AntiVirus. The update caused a fatal bluescreen crash, and the 2007 installation wiped all the history from my machine--no GoBack options. Norton Tech support refused multiple attempts to provide help; instead they told me to call another tech support number that turned out to be Microsoft fee-for-service. The aborted Norton installation could not be uninstalled by conventional means. To make a week-long story short, I Googled the problem and found out that Norton has a downloadable utility to uninstall their products. I used that to clean their products from my computer, and now the computer works perfectly again. Norton tech support should have had that solution.

Summary of Norton 2007 performance: (1) the product is in the same headache category as viruses; (2) Tech support is arrogantly incompetent.

Now do you believe us? I recommend you go get the 30 trial of NOD32 from http://www.download.com/NOD32-Standard-Version-Windows-NT-2000-XP-/3000-2239_4-10475647.html and either crack it, or get a real serial for it by buying it for a mere $40. I fix computers on my spare time, and one of the most common problems is the fact that they have Norton. One more recommendation, get Commodo, it’s the best firewall ever ;), or if you don’t feel like cracking NOD32 or buying it, get Commodo’s Antivirus/Malware, it’s free, and they really mean free.

Read full topic

item.source: Help with this faking trojan/spyware/total FAK-UP

item.title: Help with this faking trojan/spyware/total FAK-UP
item.dc:creator: @juju juju
item.description:
@juju wrote:

[quote=“ThAt0n36Uy, post:8, topic:160978”][quote author=ninja nub link=topic=219042.msg1906192#msg1906192 date=1196412787]
I have norton, don’t feel like paying more
[/quote]

Sorry to be so blunt. But you’re fucking stupid.

Why not pay a small $150.00 or so to get a good malware protection program, and have for years. Rather than sit there like a Dumb ass and let the Spyware wreak havoc on your PC. It doesn’t even make sense. You know after a while the Spyware can put worms on your computer and possibly to hardware damage. Not to mention if your parents pay bills online with that computer.[/quote]

Well, honestly, what’s the point in spending $150 on something that you do not know detects viruses all the time - no matter how many times you scan, once you’ve been initially infected, you can never be sure if you’re clean unless you reformat.

Spyware puts worms on computers? Huh? What hardware damage would this cause?

Read full topic
